title: PNG and the risk of the youth bulge
text:
The risk to stability

And the reason that matters, for both the company and the country in which Botten has invested so much of his working life, is that this transformation threatens, over the medium to long-term, to undermine the stability of the working environment in PNG.

“It you want to see a stable operation, a company like Oil Search with pretty much all of its assets in PNG, has got to play a significant role in helping and facilitating government to deal with the youth bulge in the country,” Botten said.

“At the moment, a lot of youth in the Highlands are smoking marijuana, they are making home brew, they have got nowhere to go and their disciplines around what they do and how they do it are diminishing by the day. So, if we don’t address ourselves to that, as a long-term play in PNG, and work with and through government, work with the Aussie government and with other partners to address [it], then in my personal view there will be a very challenging operating environment in the future.

“Even in five years time with 130,000 barrels per day of oil coming out of Alaska and with hopefully three more (liquid natural gas trains) in PNG, Alaska will still make up only about 20 per cent of our value. So you cannot forget the importance of Papua New Guinea to Oil Search. And you know, highlighting one of the things that I think is the biggest thing we need to manage is that over the life of our LNG project the population of PNG will double. And if you don’t address the disenfranchised youth in your three communities, which account for 60 per cent of the population right now, you know, the chances of you having a stable environment in 20 years time are actually quite challenging.”

Symptomatic of the growing pressures of the “youth bulge” is a collapse of the traditional structures of community governance, according to Botten.

“If you want to identify the biggest change from when I started back in ’92, it is that back then the tribal structures in the Highlands (which is where Oil Search produces all of its oil and gas) were very, very clear. You knew who you had to talk to. You knew which tribal leaders you needed to speak to and you knew things were good or bad depending on their view. You knew where the men owned the land, you knew where the women owned the land, you knew where it was owned by 40-50 people with long-term backgrounds.

“Nowadays, with a bigger and bigger youth population, the break-down in tribal structures, the advent of mobile phones and social media means it is a far, far more complicated process of managing your communities. Because they don’t have the structure, they don’t have the clear accountabilities that were so clear back in 1992. So you have moved the way you manage your communities and interact with them in a very rapidly changing social environment,” Botten said.

“It is not a one faceted solution here. It has to be multifaceted and you need friends and you need partners to address it and to make a difference.”

Orica door revolving... again

Can it be true that the executive doors at Orica’s original 1955 “skyscraper” are revolving again?

We are hearing that the Schlumberger man bought in to drive reform at Orica’s manufacturing operations, Carlos Duarte, is going to leave the business maybe six months earlier than his planned three-year term.

And, as a result, chief executive Alberto Calderon has taken the opportunity to make a few more tweaks to his senior management team, some passing, others more permanent and indicative of the challenges of sectoral disruption.

Duarte was introduced to Orica as part of the August 2017 reshuffle that, arguably, still sits as the most important in Calderon’s still-evolving attempt to thoroughly recast the way the business goes about the task of making the raw materials of explosions.

According to our sources, Duarte will spend the next six months or so seeing the ill-starred $800 million Burrup ammonia nitrate plant through the final stages of its costly and thoroughly humiliating rehabilitation.

Duarte’s departure will mean that both the new faces introduced to Orica in that 2017 reshuffle will have moved on. The first to go was Vince Nicoletti, who left the role of chief financial officer in 2018 after little more than a year in the job.

With Duarte eyeballing the Burrup problem, the bloke who runs Orica’s core Australia Pacific & Asia business, Darryl Cuzzubbo, will spend an increasing amount of time readying the manufacturing business for the introduction of Orica’s $300 million SAP project.

All about the 4S

The Simple Standard Single SAP project (4S) is due to go live in April 2020 and once that happens former BHP man Cuzzubbo – who has made a pretty good fist of re-energising his portfolio – is presently due to return to normal duties.

Internally, Orica has marketed the 4S project as “the final piece of the puzzle”. And what is that “puzzle”? It is the standardisation of manufacturing, supply chain, marketing, commercial and financial processes with the aim of improving the way the business understands itself, its suppliers and its customers.

As Calderon told me recently, under the 4S project Orica “will move from the donkeys to the space age”.

Meanwhile, Orica’s Singapore-based chief digital officer, Chris Crozier, is said to be on the move.

From what we hear, Crozier, another former BHP man whose reputation was built on a deep command of the logistics business, will take up a vice-president role in the manufacturing business where his focus will be the acceleration of Orica’s unique digital and wireless offerings. Crozier will report to Cuzzubbo.

And who is the tip to replace Duarte when Burrup’s repair is complete? That has not yet been decided but apparently the most obvious candidate, Greg Leah, is the most likely one too.

Advertisement

Leah currently reports to Duarte as the head of continuous manufacturing and initiating systems. And there has been a gathering step-change in Orica’s manufacturing operations with reliability now running above 80 per cent.

Fortescue watch

Reuters has reported that Fortescue Metals Group is in a race of two to secure the two blocks of the Simandou iron ore territory that are not owned by Rio Tinto and Chinalco.

Fortescue and Guinea’s biggest bauxite producer are said to have reached the final stage in the auction of blocks 1 and 2 of Simandou.

But sources have suggested to us that Brazil’s disaster-prone iron ore giant, Vale, is also still a runner in a race that, for all the goodwill in the world, is not likely to take anyone anywhere.
description: CEO says failing to deal with the disenfranchised of PNG's Highlands communities will expose Oil Search to challenging community instability.
